3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lb.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.00.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Pure Hive.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 1 gallon.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

We milked cows.

Butter? Made our own.

Eggs? We had our own hens.

What was the price of butter? $.50 lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Cottage cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, poultry.

How did you get fresh meat? Butchered our own.

How often did you get fresh meat? As often as we needed.

How did you preserve meat?

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized? 1915.

Did you use game? No.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? We used frozen fish only.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Frozen.

Kinds? White fish, dark fish, smelt.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.

Peas? Yes. Corn? Yes. Beans? Yes. Saskatoons? Yes.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning.

To what extent? Enough for the family supply.

Did you make your own vinegar? No.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - Porridge, sliced prune, coffee mildly sweet cream, bread and butter.

Dinner - Bread, meat, potatoes, pickles, tea, sup vegetable soup, eggs or fish, salad tea or coffee and fruit, cooked dried apples, nuts or puddings.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible). 1940

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

I never went to any store to buy groceries. Had to write out a list of the supply needed to last till my husband's next trip to Estevan. There were times when the supply was getting low and I had to plan and stretch to get along with little or possible except what we produced on our farm. We stored our food supplies in the cellar. We also kept our vegetables supply in the cellar like cabbage, carrots, beets, onions, potatoes in the old cellar spread. Had trouble the first year to pack eggs. Had trouble. The first year without loss. In a simple way without loss. Until I tried oats - a layer oats, a layer eggs not touching a little space between each egg, standing with the smaller top down. Lasted first till middle of Feb., when we started getting fresh eggs at market. We are getting fresh eggs all winter.
21. Then did we begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home-grown foods.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and observing foods in other countries. Include items not mentioned above, quality methods of preparation, prices, problems of storage, characteristics and other details. Use book of recipes if more space is needed.

I never went to any store at the city center. I had to walk to my neighbor's house when I needed supplies to carry to Will's house. We lived in a small town and had a normal amount of getting done and little extra work to do. We always got along well with our family. We always worked hard and never complained.

The cellar was full of vegetables, apples, and other things. We also had potatoes, onions, and carrots stored away.

Had trouble. The potatoes were a simple way to keep a layer of blue and white planking with a little space between them down egg standing with the smaller ones when we visited relatives. Had trouble making sure all vegetables were stored properly.
